ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: The ability to read academic writing! Although I definitely took classes before where I needed to do this, because this was a graduate course I think that I was really able to develop this skill.

I think this course sharpened my analytical mind quite a bit, and as a (probable) urban studies major, I'm incredibly glad I took this course early on to decenter the dominance of the global north that pervades coursework.
How to think critically about infrastructure as conveyors of ideology, to analyze their visibility and invisibility, their breakdown, who they are meant to serve, etc.
I learnt more about the politics behind infrastructure, and challenged the idea that infrastructure is neutral.

Developed the ability to think critically about various types of infrastructures. We considered how they relate to (and often facilitated) colonial subjugation in the global south, but also how infrastructures have served as spaces of resistance to colonialism.
how to use infrastructure as a lens to understand colonial and new liberal projects

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: PROF IS GREAT! Learned so much!

Prof is really intentional about making the seminar a productive and welcoming discussion space. Really interesting ethnographies though sometimes the theory readings were a little opaque to me. I think in general the quality of the readings varied week to week.

Strengths: Professor Gross-Wyrtzen is absolutely a strength of this course. Her energy, intelligence, and sense of humor had me excited to come to class every week. I also think a strength is that the assignments are really flexible, so you can tailor your reading responses and your final project to topics that you really care about and that interest you.

Weaknesses: I would say the biggest weakness of this course was how the readings were structured. Most weeks had multiple readings that were often quite dense and fulled with complicated theoretical concepts, but we read them together because each week was dedicated to a specific infrastructure (roads, electricity, etc.). I don't think this strategy worked too well, as I often found myself overwhelmed by the different approaches we were juggling each week. In other anthro classes I've taken, I've found that ones that focus on just one single, longer ethnographic work each week usually work really well. There's definitely a time and a place for comparative analysis, but I think that in this class I found the range of readings we had to handle and talk about each week a bit overwhelming.
Genuinely couldn't be improved. Strengths: Great professor, great readings, great classmates (might be dependent on who takes it, but in general I think this class attracts an interesting bunch)

Strengths: The course was very manageable work-wise and gave great opportunity to learn from our peers and think critically without feeling the pressure of articulating everything perfectly. Having the peer-taught class structure was really nice and allowed us to get closer as a class and put everyone on an even playing field. It was also really nice to have a partner and get closet with the as we prepared for leading the class. I learned a lot and the vibes were just great. Weaknesses: 750-1000 word discussion posts were a bit long but it honestly wasn't a huge deal. Would've loved a whole class session to work through our final project ideas and made us start thinking about them a bit earlier in the semester or maybe between the proposal and the presentations.
I really enjoyed the focus of the course, and really enjoyed discussing how we see the politics of infrastructure play out in various contexts.

Really strong set of readings that created interesting discussions. 750 word minimum for a reading response felt like a lot at first, but I ultimately enjoyed spending more time thinking about the material. No weaknesses that I can think of.

strengths are that the class introduced us to a new way of thinking about a broad range of infrastructures. A weakness is that the readings were sometimes too disparate and we didn't get to cover all of them during discussion.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES YES YES
Yes definitely! Great professor and interesting topic.

YES! ABSOLUTELY! Take this course if you have the chance because the professor is an absolute gem. The weekly class was such a gift and I was genuinely deeply excited to go to class each week. The readings are engaging and chosen well, and the professor has a really good handle on running a classroom and facilitating discussion that brings out the best in any student.

ABSOLUTELY!! Leslie was an amazing professor full of incredible insight. She created a very warm but intellectually stimulating class environment and I just learned so much, had a great relationship with my other classmates, and it was just an all-around great class!!
Yes!!!!
Yes! I really enjoyed this class, and feel it is a course that will be useful for students from different majors.

Absolutely. TAKE IT!!! It was my favorite course this semester and one of the best I have taken at Yale. Readings were great for the most part and I really enjoyed learning more about infrastructures in the global south. I took this as an urban studies credit -- felt more global than a lot of the other URBN courses I have encountered.
I would recommend this class to another student because it is rare to find a class that focuses on the global south and critically engages with developmental topics within that area.
